Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the findings of the CDC study by stating that face masks do little to prevent the spread of Covid-19, while the study actually found that mask mandates were associated with reductions in Covid-19 case and death growth rates.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or data to back up its assertion that face masks have little impact on preventing the spread of Covid-19.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption by taking a single study and generalizing it to represent the overall effectiveness of face masks in preventing the spread of Covid-19. It fails to consider other studies and evidence that support the use of face masks as an effective measure.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to acknowledge alternative explanations for the findings of the CDC study, such as the possibility that other factors, such as social distancing measures, may have contributed to the observed reductions in Covid-19 case and death growth rates.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the CDC study actually found that mask mandates were associated with statistically significant decreases in Covid-19 case and death growth rates.
